data.title: Crack house killing: Ex-addict says Daniel Harris told her he 'shot somebody'
data.meta_description: That someone, authorities say, was Matthew Harrell, who died in a city crack house from three bullet wounds on Feb. 20.
data.text:
An ex-crack cocaine user testified this afternoon that she was terrified when Harrisburg drug dealer Daniel C. Harris told her he shot someone in February.

That someone, authorities say, was Matthew Harrell, who died in a city crack house from three bullet wounds on Feb. 20.

Lindsey Moyer told a Dauphin County jury on the third day of Harris' murder trial that Harris was agitated when she got into a car with him soon after Harrell's slaying.

“He was really wasted,” Moyer said. “He said, ‘Some (expletive) went down at Chuck’s place and I just shot somebody.'”

Harrell, 45, was killed at a Thompson Street drug den rented by Chuck Long.

Senior Deputy District Attorney Johnny Baer is seeking a first-degree murder conviction and life prison sentence for Harris. Baer claims Harris shot Harrell during an argument over stolen drugs.

Defense attorney Gary Kelley is arguing that police did a shoddy investigation and arrested the wrong man.

Moyer’s testimony was matter-of-fact.

The 29-year-old East Shore woman said she began using crack when she was 15, but claimed she has been clean for months.

She met Harris, whose street name is “D Block,” in a city alley a day or two before Harrell’s murder, Moyer said.

She said they struck a deal for him to use her car and pay her in crack. That common transaction is called a “fiend float,” Moyer said, explaining that the “fiend” is an addict and the “float” is a vehicle.

Moyer said she loaned Harris her car the night Harrell was killed. He didn’t pick her up later at a bar as arranged, she said, so she went looking and found him and the car at 14th and Derry streets.

A “Spanish” man she didn’t know was in the car with Harris, who was drunk and had a pistol in his lap, she said.

When she started yelling at him, she said Harris told her, “Just settle down. You don’t know what happened.” Then he told her he shot someone, she said.

Moyer said Harris also showed her a large bleach stain on his shirt, implying that he’d used bleach to remove a blood stain.

“How did he appear to you?” Baer asked.

“Distraught,” Moyer replied. “I think he was a little scared about what he just did.”

She said she told Harris to take her home, where he passed out on her floor. He finally left and she didn’t see him again.

Moyer said she didn’t ask Harris for details about what happened.

“I didn’t want to know,” she said. “I wasn’t raised around people like this, you know.”

On cross-examination, Kelley attacked Moyer’s credibility, noting for example that she didn’t at first tell police that Harris was drunk. Moyer insisted that although she had been using crack and drinking beer the night of the slaying, she was aware of what was going on.

City Detective Ryan Neal said Long and another key prosecution witness, Tandras Jones, identified Harris as the killer from a photo lineup.

Kelley quizzed Neal on the meaning of the street phrase, “I caught a body,” which Harris used in texting an ex-girlfriend soon after Harrell was shot.

Neal said the phrase refers to a murder.

Kelley presented evidence from the Urban Dictionary, a reference for street slang. The dictionary’s first definition did refer to murder, but a second said the phrase also can refer to having sex with a woman.

“Have you ever heard it used in a context other than murder?” Baer asked Neal.

“No,” the detective said.

Testimony is expected to conclude Thursday morning, after which Judge Richard A. Lewis will send the case to the jury.
